options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Framework for thinking about the origins, evolution, and mechanisms of white supremacy

This class helped me in analyzing spaces. Being able to look at community issues through a sociological and ethnographical lens can help put into perspective why certain issues are persistent in certain communities.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Anderson has a lot to teach but this class is not a seminar. It's a 2-hour lecture. There are no contributions from students and Professor Eli talks two-hours straight. There is absolutely no structure for this course and he does not follow the syllabus. There is no indication of when reflection papers due, the frequency of them, or the length that is expected. One time, we had three 6 page reflections due almost back to back and then had to prep for a 10-12 page midterm essay. Also, the information that Professor Anderson provides is incredibly repetitive. Lectures contained the same information every week and it didn't matter whether or not people did the readings. I think Professor Anderson has a lot of amazing knowledge and information to share but he needs a ridiculous amount of help when it comes to structuring this course. The DUS should also consider changing it from a seminar to a twice a week lecture as well.

Professor Anderson has some incredible, illustrative stories. He does tend to repeat those stories a lot throughout the semester though and the class eventually becomes really repetitive. Professor Anderson also springs somewhat unreasonable assignments on you at the last second (example; write a 10 page paper due next week comparing an entire book you were to read for last week's class to another book you're supposed to read for next week's class)
I encourage anyone interested in any form of sociology to take this course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Thought this worked well over Zoom
I do not think any of the lectures were recorded, so maybe in the future, recording the lectures could benefit students in case they miss the live class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, Professor Anderson is a genius, and the way he explains race relations is great.
No, I would not recommend this course to any people of color, especially since students do not get to provide their own life experiences and contribute to the conversations.
Getting to take a class w/ Professor Anderson is an incredible opportunity. But be warned-- the class centers around a few themes and those themes get repeated over and over again.
